meta.title: Solve Everything — Glossary
meta.description: 140-term dictionary for the Solve Everything framework. Load on demand when term definitions are needed.

glossary.Abundance Targets: Public, transparent, and rigorous goals that trigger automatic funding or action when met. Unlike traditional goals, these are tied to Blinded Clears and financial rewards.
glossary.Accelerated Closed-Loop Scientific Metho: A research cycle where AI agents hypothesize, execute physical experiments via robotic labs, and analyze results in rapid iteration without human intervention.
glossary.Action Surfaces: The interfaces (APIs, robotic fleets) that allow digital AI decisions to flow outward and affect the physical world.
glossary.AGI (Artificial General Intelligence): The milestone where an AI system is as capable as a median human expert across all economically valuable tasks.
glossary.Algorithmic Scaffolding: The management layer surrounding a raw AI model that turns probabilistic outputs into reliable, agentic problem-solving workflows (e.g., via critique, verification, and refinement steps).
glossary.Alpha: Used strictly to denote a theoretical informational advantage regarding technological trends; not to be confused with financial return in an investment context.
glossary.Antitrust 2.0: A regulatory approach focused on ensuring open interfaces and preventing walled gardens rather than just breaking up companies based on size.
glossary.ASI (Artificial Superintelligence): The moment AI exceeds human capability by orders of magnitude (specifically systems trained on 10^29 FLOPs or more).
glossary.Assembler Problem: The control theory challenge in nanotechnology of programming a molecular machine to place atoms precisely without thermal interference.
glossary.Atomically Precise Manufacturing (APM): The use of programmable molecular machines to build structures with atomic precision (often referred to as True Nanotechnology).
glossary.Automated Regulator: A system that instantly revokes an AI's credentials if its live performance or safety metrics drift off established benchmarks.
glossary.Avoided-Loss Accounting: An economic metric tracking dollars saved and lives protected by preventing disasters, compared to historical baselines.
glossary.Bio-Fab: A facility or utility that manufactures biological tissues and organs on demand, treating biology as a manufacturing discipline rather than a donor-based scarcity.
glossary.Biofab SLAs: Service Level Agreements guaranteeing delivery times and rejection rates for manufactured organs and tissues.
glossary.Biological Age Velocity (BAV): A metric measuring the rate of change in biological age relative to chronological age, with a goal of negative velocity (rejuvenation).
glossary.Blinded Clears: A testing mechanism where an AI system is evaluated on data it has never seen before to ensure it has truly solved a problem rather than memorized the answer.
glossary.Calibrated Abstention: A scoring mechanism that rewards an AI for saying 'I don't know' rather than guessing when its uncertainty is high.
glossary.Capability Accounts: Real-time balance sheets of a nation's or city's productive power (replacing GDP), measuring potential rather than transaction volume.
glossary.Capacity Contract: A contract awarded to AI agents that clear reliability targets, granting them authority to manage a portion of the power grid.
glossary.Carbon Intensity: The greenhouse gas footprint associated with the production of a specific unit of food or energy.
glossary.Circuit Breakers: Software-based safety mechanisms embedded in infrastructure that automatically trigger if a system deviates from safety parameters.
glossary.City Outcome Ledger: A public dashboard showing a city's real-time performance on basic services like water, power, and education.
glossary.Civic Intelligence Literacy: The essential civic skill of understanding how to query AI systems, audit their decision logs, and challenge their outputs.
glossary.Clean-Energy Abundance: The state of having infinite, carbon-free baseload power, primarily via fusion and space-based solar.
glossary.Closed-Loop Labs: Research facilities running 24/7 where AI handles the entire design-make-test cycle without human intervention.
glossary.CO₂e Ledger: An economic metric tracking the cost per ton of carbon equivalent durably removed from the atmosphere.
glossary.Compute Portfolio Managers: A corporate role responsible for managing an organization's investment in cognitive resources and measuring Return on Cognitive Spend (RoCS).
glossary.Compute-Lend-Lease: Geopolitical agreements to stream high-fidelity intelligence to allies, binding their economies to a specific technical stack.
glossary.Compute-for-Outcomes Auctions: A government funding mechanism where blocks of state-secured computing power are auctioned to consortia guaranteeing the best solution to a public problem.
glossary.Conductors of Intelligence: A new human role that replaces managers. These individuals direct and orchestrate AI systems to achieve high-level goals rather than performing the rote work themselves.
glossary.Continuous Compliance: Systems that check if regulations are being followed in real-time, replacing periodic audits.
glossary.Counterfactual Pack: A set of difficult, adversarial test cases designed to force an AI agent to fail or ask for help, used to prove harness integrity.
glossary.Coverage Drift: A failure mode where gains pool at the top (e.g., bespoke AI doctors for the rich) while the general population receives generic or inferior service.
glossary.D2P24 (Design-to-Part-to-Verification in: A manufacturing benchmark measuring the percentage of products delivered within 24 hours of specification with first-pass yield.
glossary.Data Fiduciaries: Neutral entities that hold public data in escrow, granting access to problem-solvers while preventing data monopolies.
glossary.Data Leakage: A form of cheating where an AI model performs well on a benchmark because it has memorized the answers from the test set rather than learning the underlying logic.
glossary.Decision Records for AI Systems (DR-AIS): Immutable, public logs that detail exactly why an AI made a specific high-stakes decision, serving as a black box flight recorder for algorithms.
glossary.Decoupling Factor: A Brain-Computer Interface metric measuring the ability to operate digital devices with zero reliance on physical muscle movement.
glossary.Defect Density: A nanotechnology metric measuring errors at the atomic lattice level.
glossary.Digital Twin: A perfect virtual copy of a physical system (factory, body, planet) used for simulation and prediction.
glossary.Disaster Recovery for AI Systems (DR-AIS: Public protocols for recovering from system failures (often used in conjunction with Decision Records).
glossary.Dynamic Leash: A permission system where an AI's authority to act is tied dynamically to its live safety score.
glossary.Effective Data Rate (EDR): A Brain-Computer Interface metric measuring bits-per-second transfer speeds.
glossary.Energy-to-Compute (E2C) Index: An efficiency metric measuring how effectively a system or nation converts raw energy into useful cognitive work.
glossary.Epistemic Humility: The engineered capability of an AI to recognize the limits of its own competence and escalate to a human expert.
glossary.Exolinguistics: The study and decoding of the statistical grammar of non-human intelligence (e.g., whales) to enable communication.
glossary.Fairness Dashboards: Public, real-time monitors of societal outcomes that flag inequalities to trigger resource redirection.
glossary.Foundry Window: The current critical period (approximately 18 months) during which the technical standards, data rights, and supply chains for the AI age are being set (hardening).
glossary.Friction of Integration: The difficulty of embedding AI model capabilities into existing real-world workflows.
glossary.Genomic Stability & Clearance Index: A composite score measuring the load of senescent cells and the accumulation of genomic instability.
glossary.Goodhart-Resistant Design: Metric design that prevents an AI from optimizing a specific measure at the expense of the overall goal.
glossary.Hidden Test Sets: Test data managed by independent third parties and kept secret from the AI model to prevent gaming or memorization.
glossary.Homeostatic Resilience Score: A metric measuring the speed at which a body returns to baseline after a stressor.
glossary.Import-Dependence Ratio: The percentage of mass (food, fuel) a space settlement must import from Earth.
glossary.Infrastructure Capital: A new investment class focused on funding the rails (primitives) of the abundance economy rather than application-layer software.
glossary.Interspecies Communication & Uplift: The domain of decoding non-human intelligence and potentially enhancing it (uplifting).
glossary.Inverse Design: The process of specifying desired properties and having the AI calculate the molecular structure that achieves them.
glossary.Learning Gain per Hour (LG/H): An educational metric measuring the verifiable increase in student skill for every hour of study, replacing seat time as the primary measure of schooling.
glossary.Legibility: The state of a domain being clearly measured and mapped, making it amenable to optimization and control.
glossary.LEV Coefficient: A longevity metric measuring the ratio of life expectancy gained per year of time passed (Goal > 1.0).
glossary.Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE): The total price to build and operate an energy plant over its life per unit of energy.
glossary.Lock-In: The point where standards and path dependencies become set, making it difficult to change the trajectory of technology.
glossary.Logical Qubit Count: The number of error-corrected, stable qubits available for computation in a quantum system (Goal: >10,000).
glossary.Longevity Escape Velocity (LEV): The point at which scientific progress adds more than one year of life expectancy to the population for every chronological year that passes.
glossary.Messy Middle: The transition period between the current state and the Solved World where the necessary industrial base and infrastructure must be built.
glossary.Multi-Objective Scoring: Scoring that optimizes a Pareto Frontier (accuracy, safety, latency, equity) rather than a single metric.
glossary.Neurorights: Emerging rights regarding mental privacy and cognitive liberty, including protection from surveillance of neural data.
glossary.Open Rails: The mandate for interoperability between AI assistants and systems to prevent walled gardens and ensure competition.
glossary.Outcome Gaming: A failure mode where an actor manufactures a problem to collect the bounty for solving it (the Cobra Effect).
glossary.Outcome Uplift: The measurable reduction in mortality and morbidity compared to a baseline.
glossary.Permissionless Composability: The ability for different systems and modules to work together and be built upon without requiring central approval.
glossary.Planetary Situational Awareness: A state of having a complete, real-time Digital Twin of the Earth, allowing for prediction and mitigation of natural disasters.
glossary.Policy Sandboxes: Simulation environments where laws and regulations are tested for impact before being passed.
glossary.Predation Index: An ecological metric measuring how many calories in an ecosystem are derived from suffering or killing (Goal: 0%).
glossary.Predictive Cross-Validation: Measuring a model's accuracy on data it has never seen before.
glossary.Predictive Immunity: A state where natural disasters are predicted with sufficient lead time to avoid all loss.
glossary.Predictive Loss: A metric used to compare competing physics theories based on their accuracy against shared data.
glossary.Preservation Fidelity: The verified completeness of neural captures for non-human species.
glossary.Programmatic Consent Vaults: Secure digital lockers where patients control their own data permissions.
glossary.Programmatic Down-Shifting: An automatic safety mechanism that throttles an AI system's permissions or speed if its live performance or safety metrics degrade below a set floor.
glossary.Proof Robustness: A measure of a software system's resistance to adversarial perturbations or attacks.
glossary.Q-Factor (Plasma Gain): The ratio of fusion power produced to heating power injected.
glossary.Quantum Supremacy in Training: The demonstration of an AI model trained on a QPU achieving a loss rate impossible for classical training to match.
glossary.Quiet Hum: The state of a Solved World where systems work so reliably they fade into the background.
glossary.Rails: The fundamental infrastructure of the abundance economy, including targeting platforms, audit tools, data trusts, and compute escrow services.
glossary.Rails Fund: An investment vehicle that invests exclusively in the primitives of the abundance economy rather than applications.
glossary.Reciprocal Stewardship: A protocol for interacting with non-human intelligence that favors consensual uplift and partnership over isolation.
glossary.Red-Team Endowments: Permanent funds paying white-hat hackers to find flaws in AI systems.
glossary.Regulation by Automated Oversight: A regulatory model where provisional licenses are granted based on real-time performance monitoring rather than prior restraint.
glossary.Reliability Minutes Avoided: An infrastructure metric measuring the prevention of power outages.
glossary.Replication Pack: A downloadable, cryptographically signed file containing code, proofs, and logs that allows any third party to independently verify a scientific claim or engineering result.
glossary.Retention Floors: Educational metrics ensuring students still know material 30, 60, and 180 days later.
glossary.Schedulable Compute: Data centers that act as demand-response assets for the power grid, ramping usage up or down to balance renewable energy supply.
glossary.Secure Openness: A security strategy based on Open Procedures, Private Keys and multi-source redundancy rather than secrecy.
glossary.Spec-to-Artifact Score: A metric measuring the percentage of times an AI system produces a working output that matches the specification on the first try.
glossary.Standards Diplomacy: The use of technical standards, safety protocols, and data rights as tools of foreign policy and soft power.
glossary.Substrate Independence: The ability for human consciousness to exist and function on non-biological hardware (silicon).
glossary.Sustainability Ledger: Attested records tracking the energy and carbon intensity per unit of production.
glossary.Synthetic Shift: The transition from training AI models on historical human data to training them on high-fidelity synthetic (simulated) data.
glossary.Throughput Ledger: A record tracking output per kilowatt-hour, per hour, and per dollar to verify industrial efficiency.
glossary.Time-to-Property (TtP): A materials science metric measuring the time required to go from a digital design of a material to a physical sample with verified properties.
glossary.Time-to-Therapy (TTT): A healthcare metric measuring the time from diagnosis to personalized intervention.
glossary.Two-Source Rule: A safety mandate requiring critical decisions to be confirmed by two independent AI systems.
glossary.Two-Stack Rule: A safety mandate requiring critical software systems to be verified by two independent AI toolchains.
glossary.Unification Score: A physics metric rewarding models that can explain multiple phenomena with a single theory.
glossary.Universal Bio-Factory: A theoretical industrial platform capable of printing or growing any biological tissue or organ on demand.
glossary.Universal Quality Floors: A fairness mechanism that rejects an AI model if its reliability degrades for any specific population segment, even if the aggregate score improves.
glossary.Virtual Cell: A high-fidelity, atom-by-atom simulation of cellular biology that allows for in-silico drug testing and disease modeling, effectively turning biology into a software problem.
glossary.Zero-Defect Corridor: A manufacturing guarantee that defects remain below a strict parts-per-million count.
